xyz.acygn.mokapot.wireformat

Interface ReadableDescription

  • All Superinterfaces:
    DataInput
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ObjectDescription

    public interface ReadableDescription
extends DataInput
    An object that can be read the same way as an ObjectDescription. In other words, it can read a sequence of bytes (representing the copiable portion of the description) as various data types, and also return objects from a separate sequence of objects.

    Unlike ObjectDescription itself, this class does not necessarily need to have the data stored concretely in fields ready to return instantly; reading from it can generate the required data on the fly, and may have side effects.

    Author:
    Alex Smith

      Reads a number of bytes from the description, outputting them as a ByteBuffer.

        readBoolean, readByte, readChar, readDouble, readFloat, readFully, readFully, readInt, readLine, readLong, readShort, readUnsignedByte, readUnsignedShort, readUTF, skipBytes

    • Method Detail

      • readNoncopiableObject

        <T> T readNoncopiableObject(Class<T> asClass)
                     throws IOException
        Reads an object from the noncopiable portion of this description. This operation can only be done reliably if the actual class of the object to read is already known. Note that if the wrong class is given, it may not be possible to detect this fact (although a ClassCastException may well be thrown in cases where it is detectable).
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class of the object to read.
        Parameters:
        asClass - T.class, given explicitly due to Java's type erasure rules.
        Returns:
        The object that was read.
        Throws:
        IOException - If there is no object to read, or if something goes wrong trying to read the object

      • readByteSlice

        ByteBuffer readByteSlice(int length)
                  throws IOException
        Reads a number of bytes from the description, outputting them as a ByteBuffer. This might potentially share its backing storage with the description itself, so is more efficient than using a byte array in cases where it's possible to operate on buffers directly.
        Parameters:
        length - The number of bytes to read.
        Returns:
        A buffer holding the read bytes.
        Throws:
        IOException - If there is no capacity in the buffer
